prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 J=2-1 transitions
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HCO+, HCN, HNC, and HOC+ J=2-1 transitions

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We estimate the flux density F(A) and F(B) of the two blazar images A and B as F = F0 (nu/nu0)^-alpha. We take alpha=0.7, F0(A)=0.5 Jy at 100 GHz (based on our previous PdBI observations), and a magnification ratio A/B=4. This gives F(A)=0.4 Jy and F(B)=0.1 Jy for this tuning. We target a sensitivity of 1 sigma on 1% of the continuum level (ie on tau=0.01) toward image A (where the absorption occurs), that is 4 mJy, for a velocity resolution of 1 km/s (sufficient to get the line integrated opacities).

We want to cover mainly the lines of HCO+, HCN, HNC, and HOC+ J=2-1, with velocity resolution of ~0.5 km/s (the deepest velocity component is about 5 km/s wide, we want to resolve the profile for these strong lines). In addition we set basebands to transitions of CH3OH and c-C3H2, with lower velocity resolution of ~1km/s (we are just interested in the detection of those lines, and their line integrated intensities), plus a continuum band to help calibrating the data (including self-calibration). We can find no potentially detectable lines in this continuum band. The setup is optimized to cover all the lines of interest, within the tuning, and minimizing the data rate.

We request any configuration capable of delivering angular resolution better than 0.6''. The separation between the two bright and compact (ie point like) lensed images of the blazar is 0.3''. We will self-calibrate the data and perform visibility fitting to extract the spectra toward each image. The SNR will be ample enough to allow us to resolve the two images in the Fourier plane. We reckon that the ALMA beam will be slightly elongated in the NS direction, due to the low elevation of the source from ALMA site. This is not a big concern, since the two images are split in the EW direction.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B4 J=3-2 transitions
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HCO+, HCN, HNC, and HOC+ J=3-2 transitions

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We estimate the flux density F(A) and F(B) of the two blazar images A and B as F = F0 (nu/nu0)^-alpha. We take alpha=0.7, F0(A)=0.5 Jy at 100 GHz (based on our previous PdBI observations), and a magnification ratio A/B=4. This gives F(A)=0.3 Jy for this tuning. We target a sensitivity of 1 sigma on 1% of the continuum level (ie on tau=1%) toward image A (where the absorption occurs), that is 3 mJy, for a velocity resolution of 1 km/s (sufficient to get the line integrated opacities).

We request three basebands to cover the strong lines of HCO+, HCN, and HNC J=3-2, with velocity resolution of ~0.5 km/s (the deepest velocity component is about 5 km/s wide). This is best achieved with spectral windows of 468 MHz (wide enough to cover the line and give continuum signal) and a spectral averaging by factor of 2 (which will also decrease the data rate without compromising significantly the velocity resolution). In addition, we request one more baseband to cover the HOC+ J=3-2 line, with ~1 km/s velocity resolution (we expect the line to be weaker than the three others in this setup).

We request any configuration capable of delivering angular resolution better than 0.6''. The separation between the two bright and compact (ie point like) lensed images of the blazar is 0.3''. We will self-calibrate the data and perform visibility fitting to extract the spectra toward each image. The SNR will be ample enough to allow us to resolve the two images in the Fourier plane. We reckon that the ALMA beam will be slightly elongated in the NS direction, due to the low elevation of the source from ALMA site. This is not a big concern, since the two images are split in the EW direction.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B4 J=3-2 transitions of H13CO+ and H13CN

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We estimate the flux density F(A) and F(B) of the two blazar images A and B as F = F0 (nu/nu0)^-alpha. We take alpha=0.7, F0(A)=0.5 Jy at 100 GHz (based on our previous PdBI observations), and a magnification ratio A/B=4. This gives F(A)=0.30 Jy for this tuning. We target a sensitivity of 5 sigma on the peak of the H13CO+ 3-2 absorption for a velocity resolution of 1 km/s (sufficient to get the line integrated opacities). We expect the line to be of ~8 mJy based on the 2-1 absorption observed with PdBI (with Tex=4.6K). Hence the requested sensitivity is 1.6 mJy.

We request basebands to cover mainly the lines of H13CO+ and H13CN, with velocity resolution of ~0.5 km/s (the deepest velocity component is about 5 km/s wide). In addition, we set up bands to cover other isotopologues of the HCO+/HCN/HNC family: HC18O+, HC17O+, HC15N, and HN13C. The setup is optimized to cover all these lines. Data rate is minimized while still keeping sufficient velocity resolution of ~0.5 km/s and enough bandwidth for calibration. We add one pseudo-continuum band to help for data calibration.

We request any configuration capable of delivering angular resolution better than 0.6''. The separation between the two bright and compact (ie point like) lensed images of the blazar is 0.3''. We will self-calibrate the data and perform visibility fitting to extract the spectra toward each image. The SNR will be ample enough to allow us to resolve the two images in the Fourier plane. We reckon that the ALMA beam will be slightly elongated in the NS direction, due to the low elevation of the source from ALMA site. This is not a big concern, since the two images are split in the EW direction.

We estimate the flux density F(A) and F(B) of the two blazar images A and B as F = F0 (nu/nu0)^-alpha. We take alpha=0.7, F0(A)=0.5 Jy at 100 GHz (based on our previous PdBI observations), and a magnification ratio A/B=4. This gives F(A)=0.4 Jy for this tuning. We target a sensitivity of 1 sigma on 1% of the continuum level (ie on tau=0.01) toward image A (where the absorption occurs), that is 4 mJy, for a velocity resolution of 1 km/s (sufficient to get the line integrated opacities).

We request two basebands to cover the lines of H13CO+ and H13CN, with velocity resolution of ~0.5 km/s (the deepest velocity component is about 5 km/s wide). This is best achieved with spectral windows of 468 MHz (wide enough to cover the line and give continuum signal) and a spectral averaging by factor of 2 (which will also decrease the data rate without compromising the velocity resolution). In addition, we request two more basebands to cover the HC18O+ and HC15N 3-2 line, with ~1 km/s velocity resolution (we expect the lines to be weak).

We request any configuration capable of delivering angular resolution better than 0.6''. The separation between the two bright and compact (ie point like) lensed images of the blazar is 0.3''. We will self-calibrate the data and perform visibility fitting to extract the spectra toward each image. The SNR will be ample enough to allow us to resolve the two images in the Fourier plane. We reckon that the ALMA beam will be slightly elongated in the NS direction, due to the low elevation of the source from ALMA site. This is not a big concern, since the two images are split in the EW direction.

We estimate the flux density F(A) and F(B) of the two blazar images A and B as F = F0 (nu/nu0)^-alpha. We take alpha=0.7, F0(A)=0.5 Jy at 100 GHz (based on our previous PdBI observations), and a magnification ratio A/B=4. This gives F(A)=0.4 Jy for this tuning. We target a sensitivity of 1 sigma on 1% of the continuum level (ie on tau=0.01) toward image A (where the absorption occurs), that is 4 mJy, for a velocity resolution of ~1 km/s (sufficient to get the line integrated opacities).

We request basebands to cover the lines of several species (CS, C34S, H2S, H234S, H2CO, c-C3H2, CH2NH, and HC18O+). The deepest velocity component is about 5 km/s wide. We adopt a velocity resolution of ~1 km/s for this pool of lines, as we are mostly interested in their detection and line integrated intensities. The setup is optimized to cover all the potentially detectable lines in this tuning, while minimizing the data rate and still allowing for sufficient bandwidth for calibration.

We request any configuration capable of delivering angular resolution better than 0.6''. The separation between the two bright and compact (ie point like) lensed images of the blazar is 0.3''. We will self-calibrate the data and perform visibility fitting to extract the spectra toward each image. The SNR will be ample enough to allow us to resolve the two images in the Fourier plane. We reckon that the ALMA beam will be slightly elongated in the NS direction, due to the low elevation of the source from ALMA site. This is not a big concern, since the two images are split in the EW direction.

We estimate the flux density F(A) and F(B) of the two blazar images A and B as F = F0 (nu/nu0)^-alpha. We take alpha=0.7, F0(A)=0.5 Jy at 100 GHz (based on our previous PdBI observations), and a magnification ratio A/B=4. This gives F(A)=0.18 Jy for this tuning. We target a sensitivity of 3 sigma on 10% of the continuum level (ie on tau=0.1) toward image A (where the absorption occurs), that is 6 mJy, for a velocity resolution of 1 km/s. Both CH and H2O lines are expected to be strong, with tau >> 0.1.

We set up four basebands to cover lines of CH (two hyperfin groups), H2O, and H2^17O. A velocity resolution of ~0.5 km/s for the water line is appropriate to well resolve the line profile, which deepest velocity component is about 5 km/s wide. For CH, we adopt a lower velocity resolution of ~1 km/s, as we are mostly interested in the line integrated intensity (to determine the H2 column density). We do not expect to detect the H2^17O, but still place a baseband, in case.

We request any configuration capable of delivering angular resolution better than 0.3'', the separation between the two bright and compact (ie point like) lensed images of the blazar. We will self-calibrate the data and perform visibility fitting to extract the spectra toward each image. We reckon that the ALMA beam will be slightly elongated in the NS direction, due to the low elevation of the source from ALMA site. This is not a big concern, since the two images are split in the EW direction.

We estimate the flux density F(A) and F(B) of the two blazar images A and B as F = F0 (nu/nu0)^-alpha. We take alpha=0.7, F0(A)=0.5 Jy at 100 GHz (based on our previous PdBI observations), and a magnification ratio A/B=4. This gives F(A)=0.2 Jy for this tuning. We target a sensitivity of 5 sigma on 10% of the continuum level (ie on tau=0.1) toward image A (where the absorption occurs), that is 4 mJy, for a velocity resolution of 1 km/s. The C[I] line is expected to be strong, with tau >> 0.1 and will be detected with good signal-to-noise ratio, allowing us to compare its line profile with other species.

We set up basebands to cover lines of C[I] and potentially NH2 (detected toward PKS1830-211). A velocity resolution of ~0.5 km/s for the water line is appropriate to well resolve the line profile, which deepest velocity component is about 5 km/s wide. We will compare the C[I] line profile to that of other species to study the photo-chemistry. Two additional bands are set to help calibrating the data. We do not expect other detectable absorption lines within the tuning.

We request any configuration capable of delivering angular resolution better than 0.3'', the separation between the two bright and compact (ie point like) lensed images of the blazar. We will self-calibrate the data and perform visibility fitting to extract the spectra toward each image. We reckon that the ALMA beam will be slightly elongated in the NS direction, due to the low elevation of the source from ALMA site. This is not a big concern, since the two images are split in the EW direction.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Molecular absorption toward bright continuum source is a powerful method to study the physico-chemical properties of gas even in distant galaxies. Sole the molecular absorber at z=0.89 toward PKS1830-211 has been intensively studied thus far, resulting in the detection of more than 40 different species and several of their isotopologues. These molecules at z=0.89 have been used as powerful cosmological probes of the cosmic microwave background temperature, of the variations of fundamental constants of nature, and of the enrichment of the Universe via measurements of isotopic ratios. Active searches for discovering more molecular absorbers are currently under way. Here we propose to turn to the only other known absorber to date similar to PKS1830-211, that located at z=0.68 toward B0218+357. We target most of the lines detected toward PKS1830-211 to constitute a benchmark for future absorption studies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
